Award.AwardTitle: Sulfate Attack Mechanisms in Geopolymers: Measurements and Modeling at the Nanoscale

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the main contributors to anthropogenic carbon dioxide emissions is ordinary Portland cement production, accounting for approximately 8 percent of total emissions. With Portland cement production forecast to double in the next 30 years it is imperative that low-carbon alternatives are successfully implemented in industry. Geopolymer cements have emerged as viable alternatives to Portland cement-based systems, however, there is the explicit need to be able to accurately predict the long-term durability performance of these cements for the successful implementation in the built environment. Nevertheless, as is the case for conventional cement systems, the exact chemical and physical processes controlling durability are not fully understood. Degradation of concrete exposed to sulfates is a serious durability concern for both conventional concrete and sustainable alternatives. Hence, the development of sulfate resistant concrete is extremely important for a wide range of infrastructure applications including sewer pipes, storm-water drainage systems, coastal structures and foundations. The outcome of this project will be the creation of sustainable cements with superior resistance to sulfate attack, which will benefit society by reducing costs associated with repair and maintenance of concrete structures exposed to sulfates.

This project will investigate the atomic structure and morphology of sustainable geopolymer cements to improve our understanding of (i) cement formation mechanisms and (ii) chemical degradation processes caused by sulfate attack. The objective is firstly to discover the atomic processes that occur during formation of fly ash-slag-metakaolin geopolymer cement mixes by creating a geopolymer-specific atomistic modeling methodology utilizing quantum chemistry and molecular dynamics. Key characterization techniques will be employed to ensure experimental validity of the model, specifically in situ atomic analysis techniques at synchrotron and neutron user facilities, and Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy. The structural models will be used to identify the key chemical mechanisms controlling geopolymer cement formation together with the influence of precursor chemistry on these mechanisms. The second objective of this project is to uncover and control the atomistic degradation mechanisms that occur during exposure to sulfate solutions. By exploiting the stability of the atomic structures most resilient to sulfate attack, mix designs will be engineered with improved sulfate resistance characteristics at the atomic level. The modeling methodology developed during the first part of the project will be extended to enable simulation of the chemical processes that occur when different sulfate salts are exposed to the geopolymer cement surfaces. In situ degradation experiments will be conducted to provide experimental validation of the models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on determining the nanoscale degradation mechanisms of low-CO2 cements, specifically geopolymers, under sulfate attack. A fundamental understanding of these degradation mechanisms is crucial for (i) the design of geopolymer concretes with superior sulfate resistance, (ii) the development of reliable sulfate resistance testing method for geopolymers, and (iii) development of mathematic models for the prediction of geopolymer service life. These developments are of significant interest to the construction industry if geopolymers are to be used in sulfate-bearing environments.

Prior to determination of the degradation mechanisms, it is vital to have a detailed understanding of the molecular structure of the precursor materials (i.e., blast furnace slag, fly ash and metakaolin) and how the geopolymer pastes form due to an alkali-activation process of the precursors. In this project a novel approach for generating molecular structural representations of different slags was developed, which will be of relevance to the amorphous structure and aluminosilicate glass communities. The generated molecular structures of slag revealed that this amorphous material exhibits phase segregation at the nanoscale, where magnesium-rich regions are present that are devoid of calcium atoms. This phase segregation will impact the dissolution behavior of these slags. The formation mechanisms of the alkali-activated pastes were investigated using pair distribution function analysis (experimental synchrotron-based technique) and quasi-elastic neutron scattering. A novel finding of this component of the project was the determination of the enthalpy (heat) associated with the generation of bound hydrogen atoms for the dominant chemical processes occurring during formation of alkali-activated slag, based on the slopes of the bound water index (values obtained from quasi-elastic neutron scattering analysis) versus cumulative heat plot (from isothermal calorimetry data). The correlated data enabled for the different chemical processes to be explicitly identified and quantified.

The chemical degradation mechanisms associated with different forms of sulfate (Na2SO4, MgSO4 and H2SO4) were investigation for a range of geopolymers, where the findings revealed why alkali-activated slag is immune to Na2SO4 attack but prone to MgSO4 attack. Based on this fundamental understanding, the chemistry of slag was augmented, via use of a Fe-rich slag, and it was discovered that an alkali-activated Fe-rich slag exhibits superior resistance to both Na2SO4 and MgSO4 attack. The determination of the chemical mechanisms occurring during sulfate attack of geopolymers will impact the use of geopolymer concrete in the construction industry, specifically via selection of mix designs for a particular sulfate-exposure condition. Hence, this finding, specifically the behavior of alkali-activated Fe-rich slag, has important implications for construction projects in coastal areas where both Na2SO4 and MgSO4 are abundant in seawater.

In addition to the chemical degradation mechanisms responsible for sulfate attack of geopolymers, the transport properties of the pastes (i.e., movement of ions/water molecules through the pore network) also contribute to the rate of degradation caused by sulfate exposure. In this project, permeability data were obtained using the beam-bending technique, with the results reconciling differences in the publicly-available data regarding the permeabilities of various types of geopolymers. Hence, in a similar fashion to the sulfate attack results mentioned above, these results will help industry select which geopolymer is best suited for a certain concrete application, where low permeability is necessary for reinforced concrete structures.

All data (raw and processed) associated with this project have been uploaded to DataSpace at Princeton University for long-term storage and access. The analysis and interpretation of data are given (or will soon be given) in peer-reviewed journal articles. Furthermore, the graduate PhD thesis will be made publicly available through Princeton University in summer 2019. This project has supported three graduate students and an undergraduate student conducting independent study, together with providing several undergraduate summer interns with research experience. Lastly, this project has enabled the PI and students to participate in outreach activities including public seminars, science fairs and on-site tours, where the general public was introduced to the sustainability aspects of the concrete industry and innovative alternatives that have the potential to substantially lower the industry’s CO2 emissions.
